marketing is not nearly as complex as private sector marketing for a variety of reasons, but the principles in marketing, advertising and selling are the same. In this article, we’re going to look at just some of those similarities.
One common misconception about marketing is that advertising and promotion are the most important components of marketing, but the most important component is public relations. The creation and maintenance of good will, both in the media and on the public’s general mind, is a difficult task, but one worth doing really well.
Government agencies are not immune to harsh criticism. Consider the Department of Homeland Security following September 11, the General Motors embargo in Ontario following the auto bailout and bailout scandal, and more recently the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. People are quick to remember the negative things about government agencies, but they don’t remember the positive things they did unless everything that agency did was positive; also, the negative things that agenices did. Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a compromise on raising the nation's $14.3 trillion debt ceiling could call into question the United States' prestige as the world's biggest economy and leading reserve currency, Lew cautioned in early remarks.
Congress faces two major deadlines that loom large depending on how you look at it. A lapse in approval for new government spending starting the beginning of the work week could shutter offices, leave thousands out of a job and put a fine point on the divisions between Democrats and Republicans.
While most experts agree a full-blown default is not possible — the U.S. government would nevertheless default — many warn that if Congress does not raise the debt ceiling sometime before Oct. 1 lawmakers could trigger an international financial crisis.
In the ensuing three weeks of fruitless debate about the nation's spiraling borrowing bill, U.S. interest rates would shoot upward, the Washington Post reports.

of diarrhea. These helpful foods help maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.
Often people recover from diarrhea when they begin to consume enough fruits and vegetables and liquids to replace the fluid lost during the episode.
This article covers various foods and drinks occurring in each food group that can promote healthy digestion. If one’s diarrhea is persistent or excessive, they should seek out a doctor’s advice regarding the problem. Likewise, it is always best to consult with a doctor before making any big dietary changes.
Apple juice, pears, bananas, and rice may be excellent options. They often cause the least amount of irritation and help to gently return the bowel to regular order. They are good foods to adopt for the initial symptoms and can be consumed throughout the duration of the episode.
Apple juice is a natural remedy for diarrhea. This juice is useful because it simultaneously re-hydrates and restores electrolytes lost during illness.

This makes Israel No. 4 in the world in General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) in year 2015. See the global rankings for that indicator if you're looking to compare any other country with Israel. One can see all the rankings for the 2015 indicator, including those of Israel, ordered by rank.
Definition: General government structural balance refers to the actual less cyclically adjusted primary balance divided by potential GDP. The structural primary balance erases the repercussions coming from cyclical influences on the actual primary balance. For instance, when an economy is in a recession, the actual primary balance will automatically be worse than if the economy were at potential GDP, only because of the business cycle, not because of any inherent fiscal policy deterioration. The cyclically-adjusted primary balance removes this effect. The adjustment is done by first deriving potential output, or GDP, and then removing the cyclical deviations of the actual economic activity using the expenditure-based approach. it is the only industrialised country whose maternal mortality-related deaths are actually increasing is pretty shocking.
In the last 25 years, the rate of women dying of complications arising from pregnancy and childbirth in the US has been increasing at a rate of two per cent each year. According to a 2013 study, more than 700 US mothers die every year of causes related to pregnancy or childbirth. This puts it higher than Mexico, Turkey, Chile and Uzbekistan in terms of deaths related to complications arising from pregnancy and childbirth. The UK, Canada and Sweden have mortality rates around one per ten thousand. The US has a rate of 17 for every ten thousand births. That is an increase of 50 per cent since 1987.
The United States simply spends less on healthcare per patient than it does in other developed countries.
What is causing this to happen in the US and not anywhere else?
Differences between countries vary dramatically. In Colombia two-thirds of women receive no prenatal care during pregnancy,

3. Diascia personata is a drought-hardy plant which will rot if over watered. Once established – as a specimen plant at the back of the border or as a focal point, it’s one that will survive as a rogue plant for a considerable time.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government marketing is not nearly as complex as private sector marketing for a variety of reasons, but the principles in marketing, advertising and selling are the same. In this article, we’re going to look at just some of those similarities.
One common misconception about marketing is that advertising and promotion are the most important components of marketing, but the most important component is public relations. The creation and maintenance of good will, both in the media and on the public’s general mind, is a difficult task, but one worth doing really well.
Government agencies are not immune to harsh criticism. Consider the Department of Homeland Security following September 11, the General Motors embargo in Ontario following the auto bailout and bailout scandal, and more recently the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. People are quick to remember the negative things about government agencies, but they don’t remember the positive things they did unless everything that agency did was positive; also, the negative things that agenices did. The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, has now upgraded processed meat to “Group 1” – the most dangerous category in their classification system.
It follows the classification of alcohol, asbestos, tobacco and ultraviolet radiation.
‘Cause of cancer’
“Red meat,” the report concluded, “probably being in Group 3.”
It said processed meat, such as sausages and bacon, “caused cancer”, and red meat – beef, pork and lamb – appeared to most likely cause cancer too but data were limited.
It wasn’t all bad news though: eating red or processed meat in moderation posed no danger
For instance, the report stated that elderly Frenchmen who eat only one sausage per week have a seven per cent higher chance of developing colorectal cancer.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market jitters.
Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a compromise on raising the nation's $14.3 trillion debt ceiling could call into question the United States' prestige as the world's biggest economy and leading reserve currency, Lew cautioned in early remarks.
Congress faces two major deadlines that loom large depending on how you look at it. A lapse in approval for new government spending starting the beginning of the work week could shutter offices, leave thousands out of a job and put a fine point on the divisions between Democrats and Republicans.
While most experts agree a full-blown default is not possible — the U.S. government would nevertheless default — many warn that if Congress does not raise the debt ceiling sometime before Oct. 1 lawmakers could trigger an international financial crisis.
In the ensuing three weeks of fruitless debate about the nation's spiraling borrowing bill, U.S. interest rates would shoot upward, the Washington Post reports.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items, including $2,799 DKNY shoes, $1,499 Versace gold-tone watches and up to 68 percent off luggage. That’s in addition to an array of nationally advertised brands such as Harry & David chocolate-covered strawberries, Evel Knievel dolls, KidzHelp nonslip buffing pouches and 2,500 pounds of sausage from Ben’s Sugar Shack of Long Valley, New Jersey.
One thing QVC’s not sending to market: deals that are too darn good to pass up. “It is not our brand,” said Mike George, the company’s chairman and CEO. “We will all go get the specials, the bargains and the close-outs, which we are not.” Adds George: “That’s not who we were, in previous times, and that’s not who we are now or who we want to be.”
Retailers will be battling for hundreds of millions of dollars in consumer Black Friday holiday dollars this weekend. Research firm ShopperTrak

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. These helpful foods help maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.
Often people recover from diarrhea when they begin to consume enough fruits and vegetables and liquids to replace the fluid lost during the episode.
This article covers various foods and drinks occurring in each food group that can promote healthy digestion. If one’s diarrhea is persistent or excessive, they should seek out a doctor’s advice regarding the problem. Likewise, it is always best to consult with a doctor before making any big dietary changes.
Apple juice, pears, bananas, and rice may be excellent options. They often cause the least amount of irritation and help to gently return the bowel to regular order. They are good foods to adopt for the initial symptoms and can be consumed throughout the duration of the episode.
Apple juice is a natural remedy for diarrhea. This juice is useful because it simultaneously re-hydrates and restores electrolytes lost during illness.
Pears can be a great fruit to consume when fighting belly discomfort. It’s best to eat them

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this “yield-composting,” where investors comb the world for the best yields, is the most risky sources at the best price. In the grand scheme of things, the worse the housing bubble in the U.S., the great the farmland bubble in Canada or the terror in the Ukraine. All roads lead to 12,000 bpd of oil and 23% decline in global energy prices. If it is worth it, all these risks can be managed – diversified global is here to stay.
Until yesterday when Saudi Arabia led a major OPEC production cut, demand uncertainty and a global economic meltdown came to the fore: in effect, demand-supply balance will kicked. And OPEC is losing a very signficant chunk of its bargaining lever that it had built up in the eyes of investors – best yield for nothing has just been taken off the table now.

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft contracts to supply 39 military helicopters for Dh2.3 billion (US$625.8 million) and to supply eight Schweidmacher guided bombs for Dh414 million.
These are the first orders under a series of US defence projects by the Emirates last year. Some contracts, however, may have referred to F-16 fighter jets which played a key role in American military operations in Libya early last year. Some reports suggested the UAE had bought 48 of these widely used warplanes.
These new projects will reinforce "international stability, military peacekeeping and capacity-building programmes worldwide", Patrick Thonissen, the acting deputy under secretary of defence for industrial policy, said last Friday without mentioning the UAE directly.
"They advance US Department of defence industrial policy objectives for achieving greater overall balance in the current international security environment," he said.
Up to 95 per cent of these exports are made in the US.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters’ recent repudiation of the administration’s spending. His expansive, unabashedly liberal message included recognizing gay couples in civil marriages and expanding theouses, and helping low-income people pay for heating oil.
Moderates in both parties urged the president to move cautiously, and his advisers, after listening to early polling, are taking his soaring rhetoric as a mandate — not a cause for caution.
“This is not cave-in time. This is not hide time. This is the time to fight with everything you have got,” former Labor Secretary Robert Reich said, as a political adviser to Obama in his West Wing office.
The president was swiftly making clear his intent on Thursday with a trip to Florida.
He held a roundtable to celebrate the health care law with middle-class families earlier Thursday, arriving at the White House’s East Room shortly before 9 a.m. He departed on an open bus at roughly 9:10 a.m. for a trip to Florida to deliver remarks on entrepreneurship at a community college

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through 2024 to assist firms with rebuilding and repowering existing medium and heavy-duty trucks and buses through rebates.
DERA also aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 250,000 metric tons annually through 2030.
The U.S. House of Representatives passed DERA with a vote of 288-129, largely along party divides. Democratic Sens. Richard Blumenthal (Conn.), Kirsten Gillibrand (N.Y.) and Ron Wyden (Ore.) co-sponsored the Senate DERA bill, which successfully passed 25-0.
The EPA is mandated to award rebates to eligible entities based on applications and project descriptions that limit NOx, greenhouse gas emissions and particulate matter.
Compliance for the House and Senate versions of DERA expired on Sept. 30, 2018.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit (or surplus) less the effects of the economic cycle.
This makes Israel No. 4 in the world in General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) in year 2015. See the global rankings for that indicator if you're looking to compare any other country with Israel. One can see all the rankings for the 2015 indicator, including those of Israel, ordered by rank.
Definition: General government structural balance refers to the actual less cyclically adjusted primary balance divided by potential GDP. The structural primary balance erases the repercussions coming from cyclical influences on the actual primary balance. For instance, when an economy is in a recession, the actual primary balance will automatically be worse than if the economy were at potential GDP, only because of the business cycle, not because of any inherent fiscal policy deterioration. The cyclically-adjusted primary balance removes this effect. The adjustment is done by first deriving potential output, or GDP, and then removing the cyclical deviations of the actual economic activity using the expenditure-based approach. Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that it is the only industrialised country whose maternal mortality-related deaths are actually increasing is pretty shocking.
In the last 25 years, the rate of women dying of complications arising from pregnancy and childbirth in the US has been increasing at a rate of two per cent each year. According to a 2013 study, more than 700 US mothers die every year of causes related to pregnancy or childbirth. This puts it higher than Mexico, Turkey, Chile and Uzbekistan in terms of deaths related to complications arising from pregnancy and childbirth. The UK, Canada and Sweden have mortality rates around one per ten thousand. The US has a rate of 17 for every ten thousand births. That is an increase of 50 per cent since 1987.
The United States simply spends less on healthcare per patient than it does in other developed countries.
What is causing this to happen in the US and not anywhere else?

Carolina (3-3) lost to Seattle (6-1) for the second straight season. This time it was in the suddenly souped-up Superdome, home of the NFL championship game.

But it became unsafe to continue, and Smith came off the field. He said he was unsure if he could ever play again.

Total revenue rose 7.7 percent to $6.4 billion, excluding revenue from its Converse footwear business in China and impacts from changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
The company’s quarterly earnings drop of more than 18 percent reflected the inclusion of impairment charges incurred by Converse (NASDAQ: CNXS) in connection with the forced closure of warehouses and other facilities in China.

“The entry of key (comparable) competitor players in China, the closure of (former chief financial officer) Jean-Philippe’s distribution network and the beginning of investments made by Nike for expansion in China may all be providing the necessary catalysts for Nike to gain momentum in China.”

Passengers on an ICE travelling from Berlin to Saarbrücken were shocked after windows were shattered by what they believe were bullets.
Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered during the journey from the German capital to Saarbrücken. It's believed the windows were shattered by bullets fired from a nearby road.
A railway worker, who didn't want to be named, told dpa news agency that he believes the bullets were fired from a nearby road, as the speed at which they travelled through the air would support this.
Audible as the train began to approach Berlin Hauptbahnhof, the incident seemingly put an end on to New Year's Eve celebrations for all those in the carriage thinking it was fireworks. However, passengers were subsequently shocked after discovering the ornate windows had been punctured by at least a dozen bullets.
The Berlin Interior Ministry commented that there were no fatalities among the 200 passengers on board. Following the incident, an atmosphere "more like that on an airplane" was described, as anxious passengers listened to confirmation about the incident. It was said, that those in the last six carriages of the train didn't hear a thing.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as our planetary collection grows, and telescopes advance to looking at shorter timescales, previous assumptions are proving to be naive. Earlier this month, astronomers discovered the first evidence for lakes of liquid water on an exoplanet. They observed the cloud-shrouded surface of Wasat, 57 light years from Earth, as it rotated, suggesting it likely resembles our home planet.
The observations of liquid water, the study says, shows that “the environment of Earth could have been incredibly similar… in terms of a world dominated by liquid water oceans”. This finding might change the way the palaeoclimatic history of Earth is understood, according to its lead writer, Michael Fridlund from the University of Gothenburg, Sweden.

Mattel's Future: Happily Ever After?
Mattel has a plan for the rest of the year, but it seems to be playing a shorter game.
According to its most recent earnings release, Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) seems to believe that its troubles are over. Segment performance, fixed costs, and segment margin will all improve during the rest of the year "driven by strong gross margin performance."
The problem with Mattel's projections, though, is that there's no indication as to why the company thinks its situation is going to improve. That lack of reliable financial information -- when combined with the company's near-peerless brand portfolio -- could lead investors to conclude that Mattel is going to stage an improbable comeback.
You have to admit, the company is pretty big time when it comes to managing its assets. In 2013 alone, Mattel and its peers have spent a collective sum of $56 million in marketing and influencer events; that's more than twice the industry's total spending on social media.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems that grow 3ft tall. The substantial bright green stems form a rosette of long green leaves which sit all together at the base of the stems.
1. Diascia personata prefers full sun and moderately-drained or gritty soil. It’s not fussy about soil PH provided it’s alkaline. Gardeners in very heavy soil, can rock it up a couple of steps provided the plants are still able to drain freely.
2. In particularly cold areas Diascia personata will struggle to survive winter. In mild areas, the rosette of green leaves may green up in spring as the new crop of flowers develop and subsequently die back as you get into summer. In very hot areas don’t forget to mulch
3. Diascia personata is a drought-hardy plant which will rot if over watered. Once established – as a specimen plant at the back of the border or as a focal point, it’s one that will survive as a rogue plant for a considerable time.
Beginners should buy seed to plant into plugs

"All boys my age love trains, trains and buses, but thank you very much I have a passable knowledge of chickens. "I decided that as I was only five days into my flat I was not intended to have this wowing cockerel and so I grabbed it, squirted some water in its eyes and stepped on it."

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together.
Gray, who coached the 2005 Neville team that won a state championship, didn't have the ideal situation when he arrived in Monroe to coach the Vikings. He brought with him Mike Swor, a Rougon graduate and former LSU player who was his assistant.
So Gray, as he prepared for the game, turned to Swor.
"We came up with two different packages in case we needed them," Gray said. "But we had worked up a third package. That gave us five or six things to call from the sidelines, so we were prepared for a change in situations."
Airline had some talented players, including Ronnie Scallan, Wayne Westbrook, Bob Rantz and Gary Westbrook. But in those days, the Vikings' success relied upon improved defense. Airline was able to win with the skills of Reed Rathburn and Ray Sinclair.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague, that atmospheric, storied, magnificent old city, still so under-the-radar that you could wander off into side streets and find charming little cafes, elegant boutiques and quiet centuries-old churches. It was still Prague way back then, before Mick Jagger fell in love with his wife there. At night, the seedy amber aleh Mr. Quan’s lit up the block across from our aging, yet still proud, faculty residence. We took to burgundy-colored train, pulling out through the granite and iron gates of the distant forest and heading off into Solnific Valley, where we all climbed Knob Hill en masse and drank robust Czech beer.

Finland faces heightened risks from links between radical Islam and terrorism, according to a fresh report by Finland’s security and intelligence police unit Supo. The unit points to the ongoing Syrian conflict as a source of the increased threat.
According to the Supo report, the scale of the radical Salafi Islamic and jihadist threat in Finland is still small, but the number of people who issue expressions of support for both Salafis and jihadists is growing. During 2015, there was an increased number of indications that a significant number of individuals both with a Finnish background and Finnish citizens support radical ideas.
Supo estimates that Salafi-inspired Islamic extremism in Finland is currently supported by a few hundred people. Those who are linked to Salafi Islamic extremism have taken part in smaller radical Islamist projects and terror organisatons such as the Islamic State and al-Qaida.
“Salafi activism between young people is a highly visible phenomenon in the ethnic Somali Somali community and in Islamic schools as well as in networks of the Islamic Youth Association (ISYY) that serve those schools,” Supo pointed out in its report.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from concerted actions at the local and national levels, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), and an expert group in the field of sustainable development say.
The U.N.’s historic Rio+20 conference that was held last June in Brazil warned that unless world leaders agree on the implementation of a comprehensive plan to combat climate change, indications are that emissions will far surpass the limit set by the 2009 Copenhagen agreement.
This deadline prompted a push towards green economic practices that harness the synergies tied to sustainable development.
But in a special U.N. report released last week, Volker Becken, the science and innovation policy officer at UNCTAD, just underlines just how far the global economy has to go to attain desirable reductions in greenhouse gases (GHGs).

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr endorsed an advisory council report Thursday that spells out an ambitious agenda for Canada’s energy market to meet the emissions reduction targets set under the Paris Climate Accord.
The report, “Innovation & Energy Strategy for Canada,” makes 28 recommendations — each aimed at making shifts of varying scale — to support Canada’s energy industry through what the advisory council sees as a “decade of transformation.” It also calls for creation of a $30-billion fund for low-carbon projects.
Stephen Heintz, president of the Rockefeller Foundation in New York, was among those who suggested business and Canada’s government can both green up their operations and realize profit.
The report was written by a panel that includes George Mobio, the CEO of clean tech company Travois Capital. Mobio argued Gerry Butts, the natural resources minister’s chief of staff, was on the right track by asserting Ottawa will torch the 2015 federal election campaign debate on climate change. Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists for viewing complex inner eye photos for diagnostic purpose. They can also help patients stay aware of changes in their symptoms in order to take essential preventative measures.
“Ophthalmologists have a significant need for portable, accessible mobile devices for communication and photographs,” said Babak Ehteshami, MD, chief of ophthalmology at Emory, Professor of Ophthalmology in the School of Medicine at Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia.
The study is published online in EyeNet, an online publication of the American Academy of Ophthalmology.
He added, “As mobility and the ability to view real-time photos become increasingly important in our everyday workflow, smartphones are rapidly emerging to fill this niche as an affordable alternative.”
In the absence of electronic medical records, smartphones can be as helpful to physicians than a notebook.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned for nearly 10 months in Iran on espionage charges, began inside Tehran’s Revolutionary Court.
Rezaian pleaded not guilty, his attorney Leila Ahsan told The Huffington Post. The 37-year-old was accused of espionage, propaganda against the establishment, tainted Moezan, communications with evidence, and conspiracy against national security.
Iran’s judiciary, a large power in Tehran, demands the death penalty for anyone who disseminates information damaging to the regime.
The espionage accusation caused alarm, especially among pro-democracy advocates, while other charges are normal for those convicted of being journalists. However, journalists in Iran live daily under the stress of being in prison for the possibility of being thrown in prison for the length of their trial.
Iran claimed Jason had handed over classified natioanl intelligence documents to the Post, The State Department asked Tehran’s government not to execute him because he said that Americans was detained, and provided some financial security for the family.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift the drought emergency in California, except for a portion of the state near Lake Oroville, the state’s second largest reservoir. Brown has blamed the past drought on climate change.
A few months earlier, Brown lifted the emergency for the Central Valley in May. California declared a drought emergency in 2014.
Brown will use his executive power as governor to keep the emergency declaration for the part of the state around Lake Oroville, where eligible residents have used almost all of their allotted water, the announcement says.
The Oroville area will transition from the current level I to a level II drought, the announcement says. Lake Oroville, which peaked at more than 50 per cent in spring, is now almost back to pre-drought levels.
TheIncline Village-Crystal Bay area of north Lake Tahoe is unaffected by the emergency, officials said. That region is part of the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Basin.
The proclamation comes one day after Brown visited the state’s largest lake, where water levels have dropped to historic lows

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of the home fire at 2:50 a.m., said Juan Bonilla, a spokesman for the Chicago Fire Department.
Fire officials said the home had no to no smoke detectors and all four members of the family were on different floors when the fire alarm went off.
The boy’s parents were in the hallway and were able to evacuate the children, Bonilla said.
His older sister, 12, was able to escape, while his younger brother, 17 months, was able to escape down the stairs.
“The father saw the little guy and grabbed him by the leg and pulled him out the door,” Bonilla said. “It was an impressive rescue.”
Responding firefighters rushed the boy to the University of Chicago Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead at 3:57 a.m. He suffered a burn to 70 percent of his body, fire officials said.
“We are keeping in our minds and hearts the family that is dealing with this tragedy,” said Fire Commissioner Ron DeFrinzo

Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a beautiful mind. Most creditable – and amusing – of all the cricket books to be published in recent years, Sharp End of the Tongue is like a PG Wodehouse novel. Engaging, warm, delightful. It all sounds a bit rich and cloying to apply to a cricket book, but Brearley revels in the absurdities, injustices, infelicities and idiocies of the cricketing world, while mixing intelligent comment with his manifest love of the game. Brearley is a loving son and humbly follows what he knows is the right road, not easily navigated in his century’s era of unbridled materialism and boorish bad-manners. From fizzing at a conversation between Ron Hodges and Nat Fyfe, to a crushing reality check about money, love and reality, Brearley has a sly wit that bubbles alongside his compassion for fellow professionals and obstinate contempt for mediocrity. He was quick and witty, thoughtful and patient, decisive and decisive enough to use his power to enforce the rule of law. He overcame hard times and nursed the country back to health. His wit, the warmth of those people who love him, the memory of it is ingrained in treasured words and deeds.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 2016 Asean due to be held in Vientiane this month.
The announcement came following express protests submitted to Thailand’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Thai embassy in Vientiane concerning Monday’s announcement by Hidekichi Yamagaki, the First Secretary and Ambassador of Japan to Laos.

The latest regulation issued by the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism requires foreign correspondents checking into local hotels to get letters “to undertake to observe those requirements” handed them by journalists’ representatives at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Booth Motorsanack, the secretary general of the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism, told Vientiane Times newspaper that foreign journalists, who have their credentials, would be able to cover this year’s Asean summit.

The scene of the fatal stabbing of a man in his 60’s at a house on Rutland Grove, Crumlin at about 8pm last night. Photograph: Colin Keegan/ Collins Dublin.
A man in is 60s has been stabbed to death in what is believed to have been a feud-related killing in Crumlin.
The murder happened at a house in Rutland Grove at around 8pm last night. It is understood two men from two different sides of a feud drove from two different directions in the area and the confrontation happened nearby the home of the victim, local sources said.
A garda spokesman described it as an isolated incident and said no arrests had been made. Investigations are continuing. The spokesman said the attack had no links to Sharia law, drug use, or organised crime and instead was believed to be part of a "lingering settlement".
Emergency services arrived at the scene shortly after 8pm and found a man lying outside the property suffering from knife wounds. He was rushed to James Connolly Memorial Hospital but was pronounced dead shortly after 8pm. His body remains there. While a scene was preserved outside the house overnight, it was fully withdrawn this morning.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by AMR Corp.'s American Airlines, its chief competitor.
United is now matching almost all the industry's actions to address a slump in revenue: a round of fee increases, reductions to pensions and compensation, and smaller fleets and lay-offs.
Existing United flyers who check fewer than five bags a year will be the biggest losers from the charge. They were already exempt from the new fees because they pay for checked bags through miles.
United, however, is responding to a new breed of profit-hungry customer by dropping its annual fee from its mileage program. For fewer miles, flyers can still get the same benefits and discounts.
So far, the new fees have won attention within the industry and some from vocal passengers.
When American rolled them out May 4, Chicago-based American Airlines representative Tim Smith acknowledged the change was a hot topic – mainly because the cost of tickets and fuel didn't change.
"For there to be a fee in a weak economic environment was not good," Smith said.

Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers, like jalapenos, need a long warm growing season, as they are one of the most popular peppers for cultivation. They grow into healthy bushes that can reach up to one meter high and are relatively easy to care for. From spring to mid-autumn, you can reap the small plants many times for seasoning and canning.

Medium-hot peppers are used in enchilada sauces, stir-fries, or everyday salsa.
Peppers are grown in Spain, Mexico, Italy, Hungary, Romania (about 80%), the USA and Jamaica.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound impact on the Native American community.
House Bill 6 would create a commission to study patterns and industry best practices to prevent violent crimes, and establish criteria for enhanced sentencing for certain offenders that were allowed to plead to lesser charges in order to avoid a dangerous trial.
Lloyd Pond, American Indian Services chief of staff, said his agency helped over 3,300 women last year with housing and law enforcement violations.
“Over half of the women we meet with are participants in our housing programs, they say that family member or the person that’s literally living with them is literally abusive; and 90% of them are horrible relationships where there was threats, trauma, you name it, in a variety of relationships,” said Pond, whose agency said about 30% of the women are Native American.

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism is still in early 1942, when, ignorant of the Japanese's hope to conquer both Australia and Hawaii in one fell swoop, America was still responding to both Japan's attack and the lesser concurrent strike on British-held British Somaliland.
The assessment for Americans of the current Taliban would have been disappointing, like Gen. Douglas MacArthur's brusquely confident promises—every day—that American, lowland and Filipino troops together soon would vanquish the Imperial Army and reclaim the Philippine rainforests. Yet the illusion also carried secret signs of hope: East Asia was already becoming an American responsibility, and the doggedness of the U.S. Marines, abandoned in the Wester Islands to die facing overwhelming Japanese odds, was asserting values which would prove crucial for the significant global conflict about to come.

New Delhi: FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
The company had posted a net profit of Rs 1,323 crore in the same quarter last fiscal, HUL said in a statement.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Combined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) technology in the mobile phones of 10 billion consumers would give them something no computer network has been able to provide - a real-time, ground-level map of the whole world.
GPS, which combines signals from a network of navigation satellites with receivers mounted in or near vehicles, is used for automobile navigation systems today. Open networks for public use are taking over from proprietary networks of telecommunications firms.
Automobile traffic data would be a welcome bonus but much more exciting is the idea of the locations of people.
Two years ago GPS receiving chips costing up to $30 added up to multibillion dollar expenditure at a time when mobile phones were reaching nearly every adult on the planet.
Today there are GPS chips costing just $1 in cellphones almost everywhere. And they now also have memory enough to know where people go repeatedly, in what order, and even how fast or slowly, and after a short period often add up to a rollicking exposure of people's movements on a global platte like the

A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This image shows multiple events.
Sometimes, the best-designed experiments blow up the scientific world, not because they find a new undiscovered phenomena or an anti-particle weighing twice as much as a continental summit, but because they set themselves the ambitious goal to test an existing theory in an entirely new way. Such an instance plays out around the newly announced results from the IceCube experiment at the South Pole, and its ambitious 60 observatory, measuring neutrino and gamma-ray cosmic rays on the windiest and coldest spot on Earth. This picture of liquid water tracing out a brilliant ring in Antarctic ice is certainly beautiful, but like most beauty without explanation, it is simply of little use.
A core component of the Standard Model, neutrinos are one of the most basal particles and of the biggest mysteries of the Universe. They complete the third "generation" that make up particles and their associated antiparticles: leptons and quarks. In the run-up to December’s global climate change meeting, fissures are emerging between Canada and the United States, as President Obama reconciles an ambitious carbon-cutting vision with the need to boost domestic energy production and job creation.
In early October, the United States and Canada hosted a climate change meeting in Ottawa, with the stated goal of unifying around an international goal of reducing carbon emissions. In many ways, the meeting’s goals ranged from ambitious to simply unlikely to actually happen. But already, the U.S. and Canada are not seeing eye-to-eye on several crucial provisions. 
The Canadian-U.S. meeting raised expectations about the meeting entitltled the Conference of the Parties, or COP, 17, which will bring together world leaders and climate experts in December.
One important question that has arisen during the United Nations meeting is the purpose of any agreement.
“Usually these talks are based on an already agreed upon framework for a broader agreement, and that has been missing so far,” Evan Massini, the president of the Association of International Business and Economics, told Rights Link in September.

To help solve this problem, Andrew Foote and Emily Woods started Sanivation— No. 55 on the BI 100: The Creators — a sanitation startup that installs in-home toilets in East Africa and turns the waste into briquettes, which the company sells to briquette manufacturers.
“People were throwing away their poop, leaving their families, their grandparents, people vulnerable to cholera and diarrhea,” Foote said. “We want universal health care, and sanitation is very much a part of that. [We want] a dignified way for people to store their waste at home, so they’re not just going in the woods when it’s nasty weather.”
In January, Kenyan government officials announced that starting from 2019, they would start requiring all new developments to install composting toilets like the ones Foote and Woods design. The policy covers buildings for up to 50 homes, workshops and small businesses, as well as public and private educational institutions.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market where the U.S. firm trails mainly Chinese vendors. Apple is expanding its manufacturing options beyond China, where a trade war between Washington and Beijing that flared last year threw up risk, as Apple builds its iPhone stockpile ahead of the holiday shopping season. India has been high on Apple’s wish list as an important smartphone market in the world but for long the company has not set up manufacturing facilities in the country mostly because of concerns over scale and profitability. Since last year, a slew of foreign smartphone makers have started manufacturing in India as the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi kicked in generous incentives for companies setting up local factories. Foxconn is an Apple manufacturing partner, as are Taiwan’s Wistron Corp and Pegatron Corp. In July, the country’s trade ministry invited Foxconn and Wistron to make smartphones for local consumption, a move which could prompt Apple to shift some of its production from the world’s biggest smartphone market, where a slowing economy and trade war are hurting business. On Jan. 12, detectives in Montgomery County received a video depicting a 65-year-old day-care operator interacting with a 2-year-old girl. By the end of the day, the operator, Christina Dhanaraj, was under arrest for allegedly putting her finger in the little girl’s mouth and leaving it there (according to the victim). It’s not immediately clear why she had her finger in there — a court document lists “for medical purposes” — but authorities do indicate that, in addition to being a caregiver, Dhanaraj is also a nurse. Dhanaraj bonded out of jail for this incident, in which she faces one felony charge for failing to report an “abnormal condition,” and one misdemeanor count of neglecting a vulnerable adult, which carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison. The bubbly Harvey is the daughter of legal counsel Vashti Charles and elder sister of student Lance Charles. Her father is the Natural Resources and Environmental Ministry’s permanent secretary.

She applied for a scholarship from the Nelson A. Rockcliffe Fund in June and was successful.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story. This Redwood City, California-based startup believes in the social network. And specifically in a social network that college-bound students can use to share the real stuff that doesn't necessarily pop on a GPA report or a transcript.
"The whole idea of ZeeMee was that we were students like most college-bound students," said Brian Chen, one of the company's two co-founder. "We were approaching college and we were going through the traditional application process. And we realized there was a huge gap between the way we described ourselves on paper and the way everyone else described us. And this was college - you want to know what these people are really like."
Founded in 2005, the company operates a social network and currently has membership in over 2,000 high schools and 5,000 colleges. And while community growth "is not a required process and not a revenue item in itself," the company is growing :100 percent year over year, according to co-founder and CEO Mary Zajkowski.

agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.
While recovering from diarrhea, a person should eat bland, simple foods that are easy to digest and will help absorb some water from

Nevada's effective monopoly on sports betting ended last spring, when the Supreme Court ruled the ban should be lifted. And there's already a hitch that could slow bets: NASCAR this season has decided for the first time to strip drivers of victories if their cars are deemed illegal. Will fans really want to linger around the pay window another couple of hours just to cash in a ticket?

On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The more she found out, the more she wondered why more people weren’t educated about SCA, the leading causes of death in the U.S. Just a few months after Blake’s sudden cardiac

two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.

It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. You can see the smoke with the naked eye, but the hard facts are even more frightening: The research and consulting firm Energy Vision found that each cart produces the same amount of nitrous oxide as 186 cars on the road.

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise. The oceans are warming and the sea level is rising continuously. Forest cover has decreased by 300 million hectares since 1990.

The study was conducted among some 350 patients who reported issues like headaches, eyesight changes and similar vision problems in emergency rooms.
The study also included the inner-eye photos taken by the ER staff using an ocular camera.
Then the study team assessed the response of two ophthalmologists who viewed and rated the pictures on a desktop PC and did the same on an iPhone.
The results of the study, published in the Archives of Ophthalmology, show that the doctors found the iPhone images good or better than desktop images and rated them high.
While one ophthalmologist felt 53 pictures were of the same quality, he found 46 better on iPhone and just one was better on PC.
For the other ophthalmologist who participated in the study, 56 were of equal quality, while 42 were better on iPhone leaving only two better on PC.

many celebrated breakthroughs were initially met with scorn and ridicule. We've compiled 11 such world-famous ideas from the history of science and technology. The temptation, of course, is to include those ideas that were scorned and should have stayed scorned. The Star Wars prequels, say. But we're trying to run a classy operation here.
Heliocentrism Galileo Galilei, sometimes called the Father of Modern Science, was among the first and most famous to pay a price for his crazy scientific ideas. Galileo publicly promoted the Copernican concept of heliocentrism -- that the Earth revolves around the Sun -- back when the Church and even most fellow mathematicians held to geocentric model. Unfortunately, in 17th century Rome, such radical ideas were quite literally heresy. Galileo was forced to recant and spend the rest of his life under house arrest.

"If there was any threat modeling at all, it was really badly done," Gutmann, from the University of Auckland, New Zealand, said while giving a talk on Vista content protection. "Once the enemy is the user and not the attacker, standard security thinking falls apart."
Vista requires premium content like high-definition movies to be degraded in quality when sent to high-quality outputs, so users are seeing status codes that say "graphics OPM resolution too high." Gutmann calls this "probably the most bizarre status code ever."

Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster that is powered by Advanced Micro Devices Inc.s 64-bit Opteron processor.
IBM, of Armonk, N.Y., is combining its Opteron-based eServer 325 server—which targets scientific and technical computing users—with systems management software and storage devices to offer a bundled package that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
The new offering, which will be available later this month or in early December, is part of IBMs eServer Cluster 1350, which also includes bundles based on the companys BladeCenter blade servers and two-processor x335 and x345 systems using Intel Corp.s 32-bit Xeon chips.
Clusters comprise multiple servers tied together to create a supercomputing environment for users. In a related move, IBM last week announced that it was teaming with Corning Inc., the U.S. Department of Energy and the National Nuclear Security Administration to develop high-speed, optically switched interconnects for supercomputers. Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 24, 2014. Ms. Rinaldi will earn a salary of $95,000.00 per year.
Ms. Rinaldi comes to the Middletown Township Public Library after having served as the Library Director of the Margaret E. Heggen Free Public Library in Washington Township, New Jersey. During her tenure in Washington Township, Ms. Rinaldi managed 26 employees and a $2.5 million annual budget. Ms. Rinaldi has also served as the Director of the Brielle Public Library and as a Senior Librarian at the Ocean County Library, Long Beach Island Branch in Surf City, New Jersey.
Ms. Rinaldi holds a Masters in Library and Information Science from Texas Women’s College and has extensive experience in library administration, budgeting and project management. Ms. Rinaldi is credited with outsourcing material cataloging and processing at the Margaret E. Heggan Free Public Library, reducing annual operating costs by $150,000.00. Ms. Rinaldi

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market turmoil.
In coming negotiations with Republicans, who control the House of Representatives, Democratic President Barack Obama will focus on ways to create economic gains for the middle class over spending cuts, Lew said.
“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

In case you missed it, the initials ICYMI stand for the first five words of this sentence. In the event you have, indeed, missed it (ITEYH, I, MI has not taken off yet for some reason), it’s most likely because you’re not on the Internet much, particularly Twitter, where individuals and outlets deploy it every few seconds to bring links to the attention of others who may not have seen them. The New York Times now even has a section at the bottom of its app called “In Case You Missed It” with articles from previous days.
While the extended phrase has been used in conversation for a long time, the shorthand betrays an anxiety central to the Internet epoch. There is simply too much readable, viewable and listenable data for anyone to stay abreast of, as a humor piece, “I’m All Caught Up!” by Nick Mickowski in McSweeney’s, playfully suggested.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items for sale starting on Thanksgiving night. Program host Dave James plans to stay awake for 28 hours of telethon-like coverage.
The day after Thanksgiving is traditionally the biggest shopping day of the year, called “Black Friday” because it’s key for many businesses to go in the black, or turn a profit. QVC, which competes with ShopNBC and the HSN home shopping network, has not wanted to get caught up in the frenzy and has always treated it as just another day for its sales pitches, said Doug Rose, the network’s vice president of programming and marketing.
“This year, and we’ve been planning on this for many months, we really expect to join the fray with the other retailers,” Rose said.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this has little to do with the attractiveness of EM investments. On the contrary, EM economic growth is at its lowest level since the 2008/09 financial crisis while the prospect of a U.S. monetary tightening creates the potential for financial turbulence.
The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.
"If you require, say, 5 percent a year in order to cover your insurance or pension liabilities, that is not available from developed market (debt) obviously," said Colm McDonagh, head of emerging market fixed income at Insight Investment.
Brett Diment, head of emerging market debt at Aberdeen Asset Management, also sees a diversification into EM debt by pension and insurance companies. "We are seeing a broader group of investors looking at the emerging market debt asset class, including some insurers and pension funds that have not looked before."
Much of this search for yield

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft a US$171 million (Dh628m) contract for 14 UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters, which are used for tactical transport.
Separately, the US defence security co-operation agency, a unit of the Pentagon, said last week it had notified Congress of a potential sale of enhanced guided bomb units, parts, training and support to the UAE for about $290m.
The same agency said in November that in the last fiscal year the UAE became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment with sales of $7.9bn, ahead of Afghanistan ($5.4bn), Saudi Arabia ($3.3bn) and Taiwan ($3.2bn).
The spending included orders for munitions for the UAE’s F-16 fighter jets as well as a new Patriot defensive missile system and a fleet of corvettes for the navy.
The UAE purchases have been fuelled by a quadrupling of oil prices in the past decade and by continuing regional tensions, including those involving Iran

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters' worries and opposition from newly strengthened Republicans. Sharpening his focus on the economy, he offered a hodgepodge of tax breaks and other incentives to create new jobs.
For Republicans, Obama blended a mix of overtures and digs. But he mainly addressed fellow Democrats, who still can enact his agenda if they overcome fears fueled by events such as last week's stunning GOP victory in the Massachusetts Senate race.
That setback may have cost Democrats their filibuster-proof Senate majority, Obama said, but "we still have the largest majority in decades, and the people expect us to solve some problems, not run for the hills."
He accepted partial blame for the deep troubles facing his health care push, but he implored lawmakers to finish the task rather than yield to public opposition.

COUNCIL BLUFFS — The Marshalltown Community College baseball team built a nine-run lead and held on to salvage a split against NJCAA Division I No. 12 Iowa Western in Saturday’s Iowa Community College Athletic Conference doubleheader.
MCC won the nightcap 12-10 after Iowa Western claimed the opener 8-4.
The Tigers (19-29, 8-14) scored seven runs in the first inning of game two, sending 13 batters to the plate. The frame was highlighted by a Snayder Ruiz two-run single, and a Kaleb Hanks two-run triple. Ruiz finished game two with three RBIs while Hanks and Diogen Ceballos each drove in two. Jose Mieses, Ceballos and Adam Barrett had two hits apiece, both doubles for Ceballos, as the Tigers rapped out 12 hits in the victory.
The Reivers (40-14, 19-3) got seven runs back between the fourth and fifth innings to pull within two, but MCC came back with three in the sixth. The Tigers needed them all, as Iowa Western plated three in the bottom of the seventh.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through 2024 to assist firms with rebuilding or retrofitting diesel engines. The objective is for those updated engines to be able to comply with pollution standards.
The Environment and Public Works panel advanced the measure to the floor of the Senate by voice vote. Carper, the panel’s ranking Democrat, had initially authored the bill more than a decade ago with former Ohio Sen. George Voinovich (R).
“With today’s vote, we’re one step closer to making sure this bipartisan tradition, imagined and incepted by my dear friend Sen. Voinovich, will continue to boost economic growth and encourage environmental progress,” Carper added. Voinovich died in 2016.
Co-sponsors of the bill include committee Chairman John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), as well as Republican Sens. Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
Having served 37 years in the civil service, five of which as its head, Mr Lim said that based on his experience, there are four words to describe what Singapore needs in order to be a successful and sustainable nation state - "gracious society, Smart Nation".

He was speaking yesterday at the launch of his book, Can Singapore Fall? Making The Future For Singapore, which is a compilation of three lectures he delivered between September and November last year.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Cindy Thompson.
Surviving are his wife; two daughters: Heather Cramer (Laramy) of Coalport and Jessica Gates of Altoona; two sisters: Cheryl McKeen in Florida and Carol Martin of Indiana, Pa.; his mother-in-law, Joan Thompson; an aunt, Sandy Martin in Tennessee; and a granddaughter, Anna Cramer.
Bob served in the U.S. Marine Corps as a lance corporal. He retired from the Altoona Hospital Police Department with 38 years of service and also worked part-time for the Williamsburg Police Department. He was a member of Wehnwood United Methodist Church.

Lynn Blake, left, teaches two hospital employees CPR at the VVMC Safety Fair. Blakeâs passion for educating Eagle County residents came from her own Sudden Cardiac Arrest, which a bystander provided CPR and saved her life. She was just 27 at the time.
On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit (or surplus) less the effects of cyclical deviations of output from potential output. Because of the margin of uncertainty that attaches to estimates of cyclical gaps and to tax and expenditure elasticities with respect to national income, indicators of structural budget positions should be interpreted as broad orders of magnitude.

After competing many times, local artist Ann Iungerich and her husband, David, decided to share some lessons learned Saturday in an ice-sculpting workshop.
The concept was more sculptors might make for a better competition.
"We've done a lot of research and tried to figure out what's what. That was why we decided to have a workshop - what few little secrets we know, we're willing to share that with others," Ann explained.
Ann and David Iungerich taught the half dozen participants how to chop away at the ice, just using wood chisels.
"Over the years, we've learned that just wood chisels work the best for us," Ann said. "We don't bring any power tools. We just have different various sharp chisels and that's what we use."
There's typically six to eight teams each year, and the Iungerichs are hoping this workshop will expand involvement and break down the barrier for people who may be interested in competing themselves.
Although she is an artist in many other mediums herself, Ann says she had never sculpted ice before her first year. After a friend suggested she try it, Ann said, "Sure!"

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.
